title: Ticket #3622: RFE: condor co-scheduling with openstack
description:
So an idea I've had running around my head, now that brianb has exposed the .py bindings, was: "What if we were to overload a Openstack nova-scheduler driver to use condor as a co-scheduler to "share" a cluster and play nicely together."

Openstack is written in python and is very extensible, at almost every layer one can override and configure their own optimized widget. One such place, is the nova-scheduler.driver, which basically chooses the resource where openstack can schedule it's job. Using condors .py extensions one could craft a constraint query that would enable the nova-scheduler to choose resources based on that constraint (of which there could be many). There are a number of other things we could integrating the two, but it I figured I would start the percolating process here.

Ref of CERN & Openstack: http://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2013/05/150000-cloud-virtual-machines-will-help-solve-mysteries-of-the-universe/
remarks:
2013-May-14 11:42:24 by bbockelm:
Does the nova-controller have a concept of queueing requests? Or do we have to fulfill the requests "immediately" (for some value of immediate)?

2013-May-14 13:04:06 by tstclair:
Everything is entered into a configurable queue, where the schedulers can opportunistically schedule jobs from that queue. (for ref: this is the best overview I've found http://youtu.be/oWgfiqNJbzc)

2013-May-14 17:59:58 by bbockelm:
In that case, I would claim you are setting your sights too low - why not have the nova-controller participate in matchmaking?

2013-May-15 08:41:30 by tstclair:
That was kind of the goal. IIRC that is actually handled in nova-scheduler, I'm still learning about openstack so I'll definitely need a bit of time to get up to speed on it.
